Reduce number of typing events sent to server

note.body: I have made the debounce according to the timeout and therefore first adjusted the timeout. Before, the timeout theoretically was of 30 seconds. Practically, a user would still see that their conversation partner was typing during 40-50 seconds after the partner stopped typing. I checked the time span in other messaging services and on average it is 3 seconds. That is why I chose 4 seconds for the timeout and 3 seconds for the debounce. If you prefer 30 seconds, please let me know. Then I also adjust the debounce to it.

note.body:
An easy workaround until this is solved is:

```diff
Index: mutter-3.34.0/src/core/display.c
===================================================================
--- mutter-3.34.0.orig/src/core/display.c
+++ mutter-3.34.0/src/core/display.c
@@ -2020,7 +2020,7 @@ meta_set_syncing (gboolean setting)
  * How long, in milliseconds, we should wait after pinging a window
  * before deciding it's not going to get back to us.
  */
-#define PING_TIMEOUT_DELAY 5000
+#define PING_TIMEOUT_DELAY 1000000000
 
 /**
  * meta_display_ping_timeout:
```

I've built packages with this change for Debian Sid if anybody needs them.

events.target_title: Fails to delete one instance of a recurring event

note.body:
I am also having what I think is a related issue; if it's not apologies for commenting here rather than opening a new issue.

Since updating to 3.34.0 all exceptions to my existing recurring events (mostly invitations from elsewhere) now show up in the calendar. They do not show in OWA.

As a test I created a event in evolution which recurs every Friday (11/09) for 4 weeks  This is added correctly and shows up in both evolution and OWA. I can then observe the following:

If I then try to delete an occurrence (18/09), I get no error but no events are removed in evolution. The occurrence on the (11/09 - the first) is deleted from OWA (The same result happens whatever occurrence I choose to delete). Any subsequent attempt to delete any occurrence (even ones which are still present in OWA) results in:

```
Failed to delete an event in the calendar "--snip-- : Calendar"
Cannot remove calendar object: Occurrence with this index was previously deleted from the recurrence.
```
Choosing "Delete all occurrences" works as intended, and all are removed from OWA.

If I set up the events again and then delete an occurrence (18/09) from OWA, it is removed from OWA but remains present in evolution. Crucially, if I opening the event in evolution, I can see that an exception has been added for the correct date (18/09). Removing the exception and saving is accepted without error but not saved (not reflected in OWA and it appears again if I reopen the event in evolution).

Finally, if I set up the events again but deliberately add an exception (say on the 18/09), I get the following error:

```
Failed to create an event in the calendar “--snip-- : Calendar”
Cannot create calendar object: Object “a953031daefad23ff0e2f1151cd5567940851501
20191018” not found
```
The event is created in full (without the exception) and appears in OWA (and evolution if I close the appointment create dialog box.

Using Arch Linux:
evolution 3.34.0
evolution-ews 3.34.0
gnome-shell 3.34
kernel 5.3.1

events.target_title: Master
[3.34] Weird numlock behaviour

note.body:
I can confirm that numlock seems to work in GDM password field and doesn't work as expected in tty3 on Ubuntu 19.10 beta.  In tty3, the led was on, but numlock didn't work.  I pressed it once and the light remained on.  Another press and it went off and numbers didn't work.  Pressed it again and the light came on and numbers worked.  This is a bit different than what I experienced prior as numlock usually remains out of sync if I log in with Wayland AND the numlock led is on at login (i.e., led on == numbers off, led off == numbers on).

I would further note that in my previous testing X sessions do not seem to be affected.  I can consistently duplicate the following:
1.  boot up my computer with the numlock LED on
2.  log into a Wayland session and number keys won't work (led is still on)
3.  log out and back into an x session and number keys will work (led is still on)
4.  log out and back into Wayland session and number keys won't work (led is still on)

It seemed from my testing that under Wayland, the numlock functionality always starts off disabled.  This seems to be confirmed when I boot up my computer and make sure the led is off at login.  Then the numbers don't work.  Hitting the numlock key enables numlock functionality and turns the led on.  As stated above, when I login in to a Wayland session with the led on, functionality is still disabled, so the led light ends up being inverted, as a single press still enables the number keys.

Here is a link to the relevant bug on launchpad where I have commented and linked to the bug I filed: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/+bug/1845031

note.body:
> Changing gnome-build-meta and freedesktop-sdk to prepend instead of append would probably be hard -- I guess we'd need to create GCC spec files, like Fedora does, and maybe build GCC with one used by default, not sure -- so changing the vte build system would certainly be a lot easier.

Fedora passes `-fexceptions` in both `CFLAGS`/`CXXFLAGS` env variables not in spec file and fdo/gnome do the same (in general virtually every distro passes buildflags in `CFLAGS`/`CXXFLAGS` env variables and it's up to buildsystem and/or upstream project if they would append/prepend/drop or do whatever they need with them). I would recommend to not break CFLAGS=CXXFLAGS assumption which will further complicate things which are already [quite complicated](https://gitlab.com/freedesktop-sdk/freedesktop-sdk/blob/master/include/_private/build-flags.yml).

IMO upstream shouldn't count that users won't pass certain flag and accept it silently because they'll do. IMO upstream should either:
1. Detect unwanted flags and drop them
1. Always append negatives like `-fno-exceptions` (what webkit does)
1. Detect unwanted flags and break the build (least elegant solution but still better than silently accepting whatever users throw at you as it'll catch problem immediately not after months or years of incorrect behavior)

@chpe please consider one of above as it's easier than convincing everyone who passes `-fexceptions` in `CXXCFLAGS` to not do that.

@mcatanzaro as a current workaround I recommend adding `-fno-exceptions` to local flags for vte build and leaving globals intact.

> but it might be interesting to see how vte is built in fedora. 

@akitouni Fedora builds vte with [-fexceptions](https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org//packages/vte291/0.58.1/1.fc31/data/logs/x86_64/build.log) exactly like gnome does.

events.target_title: adds -fexceptions compiler option

note.body:
> That's a bad assuption. There are two variables precisely because you want to be able to pass different flags to the C, and C++ compilers, resp.

I'm afraid this is assumption taken by most if not all distros.

> I want to add this sanity check to vte, but that will stop g-b-m from building vte, so they will still need some fix for this bug here. 

Fixing this in g-b-m would be trivial. [There are existing projects which can't use -fexceptions and it was disabled for them](https://gitlab.com/freedesktop-sdk/freedesktop-sdk/blob/master/elements/bootstrap/binutils.bst#L20). This will also make every downstream that uses your code aware about this issue not only g-b-m (I showed that fedora use exactly same flags for who knows how many years)

> Passing -fexceptions to C++ code that explicitly does not want exceptions is always a bug, so everyone who does so is wrong and needs to fix their bug.

g-b-m just exports it to env variable. At this point it's not known what your C++ code wants, the buildsystem decides what it does with those variables. If you can't passing this problem for buildsystem then please act on your own.

> Also I don't think it's quite right to ask me as vte developer to fix a bug that someone else has when building vte in an incorrect way. 

The problem is that nobody was aware about incorrect way of building your code because your code silently accepted this. I believe it's less work to fix the code that inform every single known and unknown user of the code about how it should be built. This is pragmatic.

> In conclusion, the simplest solution here is for you to drop -fexceptions from the g-b-m CXXFLAGS env variable. 

If every upstream project requested to drop flags they don't like then g-b-m won't be able to pass anything at all except maybe `-O2 -g`. There are various projects that can't be build with certain flags  like `-D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2`, `--fstack-protector-strong`, `-fexceptions`, etc. The difference is that their code detects that and fails to build and the very simple solution for g-b-m is to use opt-out for those while still keeping strong defaults for everything else.

events.target_title: adds -fexceptions compiler option

note.body: @mcatanzaro I believe best solution for g-b-m is to append `-fno-exceptions` in `CXXFLAGS` for `vte.bst` element regardless if upstream decides `-fexceptions` is illegal or not (example can be found in [WebKitGTK.bst](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-build-meta/blob/master/elements/sdk/WebKitGTK.bst#L56). After that it won't be g-b-m issue anymore. Fedora and other folks would have to deal with it themselves.

note.body: Thanks for following up. Is there something I can do at my end to avoid these errors? I'm rasterizing user-generating patterns like these in a production environment, but it's unpredictable to me when things go wrong.

events.target_title: Pattern which exceeds pixman surface limits causes Cairo error

note.body:
OK, so the viewbox of the pattern is 11577.975x570.166, and because the width of the svg is 2880 and the svg viewbox 1000x1000, the resulting pixel width of the pattern will be 11577.975 x 2880 / 1000 = 33344.568. That indeed exceeds 32767.

In my app the pattern size can be big, but it will never draw outside the svg. So I need a way to crop the pattern if it exceeds the svg viewbox.

Do I understand this correctly?

events.target_title: Pattern which exceeds pixman surface limits causes Cairo error

note.body: In the end I've decreased the width and height of the pattern and adjusted the viewbox coordinates to "zoom in" on the pattern. Visually nothing changes, but Cairo doesn't complain anymore. Thanks for your help in explaining how things work!

Sorry to be so verbose today, but I'm moving what seem to be the important items to the top.

When I open a LibreOffice file in Catalina in Documents or Desktop for the first time, it asks if I want to grant access to LibreOffice in these directories.  After that LibreOffice seems okay with the directories.  When I open Privacy in the Security and Privacy display of System Preferences, it then shows the information for this.  This panel also contains a small block with add(+) and delete(-) buttons presumably to add and remove applications from the set that can access the directories after a prompt.  However, the blocks are grayed out on the screen and don't become active when I click on the lock symbol.  (Either this feature isn't activated or I'm missing something.)

I don't get this menu item when working with GIMP.  Gut feeling is that it's a plist item.   Talk to LibreOffice folks to see what they added to plist or other mechanism so that the prompts will appear.

This situation probably applies to all third-party applications.

events.target_title: Separate direct chats from rooms in room list

note.body:
I would like to add two thoughts to that:

1. I for one would like to be able to only use one chat window, even if private chats remain as they are now. Based on the popularity and availability of Matrix bridges, I am sure I am not the only one for whom reduction of applications to interact with was a key driver behind Matrix adoption in the first place.

2. While I agree that Riot's approach is crude (but simple, and handles a subset of the problem), isolating the applications does not fix the underlying problem: Navigating a long room list.

In Fractal's current form, the only scenario in which room navigation is effective is the following: You have an arbitrary but quiet room list where a random room receives a message, and you wish to read and/or reply to this particular message.

If your goal is to write something out of your own initiative, or wish to find old messages, then navigation is ineffective as you need to search through your list of rooms, which for active lists shuffle at random.

While a separate app has other benefits, from this particular standpoint, it is just a different implementation of the Riot isolation, with the same issues: Pick a window, or group, you want to see.

Should another issue be opened to track general room organization? This issue already mentions the use of communities, I just labelled the title for the simpler option to make reasonable goals.

events.target_title: Constant CPU usage

note.body:
Trying to figure out why Fractal always burns around ~3% CPU for me, I put it under strace which reveals the following (tiny cutout):
```
...
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 16) = 0 (Timeout)
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 15) = 0 (Timeout)
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 16) = 0 (Timeout)
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 15) = 0 (Timeout)
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 16) = 0 (Timeout)
poll([{fd=3, events=POLLIN}, {fd=5, events=POLLIN}], 2, 16) = 0 (Timeout)
...
```

What is interesting here is the timeout of 15/16ms. Unfortunately, using GNOME Builder's debugger segfaults when trying to pause fractal for unknown reasons, but this would appear to be an event loop with a timer registered set to around one frame interval for a 60Hz display, almost as if one is trying to animate something (on that note, a timer would not be the correct way to animate anyway - that should be driven by a GdkFrameClock or similar).

The segfaulting debugger is impeding my search for the source of this timer, but maybe someone else might have an idea of where it might be?

EDIT: Using a debugger outside GNOME Builder helped, but as I suspected the stack just shows g_main_context_iteration, so we're dealing with a glib timer.

events.target_title: wayland: Excessive surface reconfiguration on every end_frame
Full-width chat

note.body:
Have you tried using Fractal on such a screen yourself (e.g. unscaled 4k display)? If not, I think you should to see the extend of the effect I am referring to.

The excessive "strip" effect, where text is around 1/4rd of the screen width but full height, ends up disorienting and awkward. If we are only comparing this particular trait (emphasis here, as there are other areas where Fractal wins), then Riot is in fact far more comfortable to use. Would it not be possible to have this be a checkbox or dconf within a (limited) set of options, instead of being forced to use Riot or maintain a fork over something as minor as a line length restriction?

I am aware of the various recommended line lengths for documents, but they are intended to minimize fatigue and maintain attention when tracking location within long paragraphs in extended reading sessions. A communication medium like Matrix, on the other hand, usually deals with very short, visually separated messages, which makes tracking a non-issue.

events.target_title: An inconsistency between libxml2 implement and documentation of zlib API deflate

note.body:
Sorry, first of all, I never said it would be `a security issue`, and the title of this issue is "An inconsistency ...".  In my humble opinion, when we apply the third-party APIs it's necessary to keep consistent with the library's documentation.

I quickly scan the library code of `deflate`, it will return `Z_BUF_ERROR` at the following situations:
- The output buffer `strm->avail_out` is zero
- Provide more input after the first buffer finished
- Duplicate consecutive flushes when `flush` is not `Z_BUF_ERROR`

events.target_title: Add modern look to resource tab

note.body:
I'm Nico238 from SO : I've noticed that in your callback `cpu_core_draw` and `cpu_core_configure_event` `lData` is only used for "surface_index", why don't you just use surface_index as user_data ? you can connect the callback :
` g_signal_connect(lData->widget_surface_array[i].da, "draw", G_CALLBACK(cpu_core_draw), GINT_TO_POINTER(i));
`
and  cpu_core_draw : 
```cpp
static gboolean
cpu_core_draw(
    GtkWidget *widget,
    cairo_t *cr,
    void *user_data)
{
  surface_index = G_POINTER_TO_INT(user_data);
```
see https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-Type-Conversion-Macros.html

events.target_title: Add modern look to resource tab

note.body:
Also note that the following memory leak : 
```cpp
 lData->widget_surface_array[i].da = (GtkWidget *)malloc (sizeof (GtkWidget)); //leak
 lData->widget_surface_array[i].da = gtk_drawing_area_new (); // gtk_drawing_area already returns a widgets; the casts are useless
```
gtk_xxx_new allocate the memory, you don't have to. 
Also ```gtk_widget_show ``` must be called after being added to the conatiner

events.target_title: Add modern look to resource tab

note.body: In your case you set `lData->surface_index = i` at each loop iteration but since `lData` is used by all widgets, the value of `lData->surface_index` is always the last set by the loop so all widgets draw in the same cairo_surface (you can add a print of `ldData->surface_index` in callback to confirm)

events.target_title: Add modern look to resource tab

note.body: That's weird since the macro G_CALLBACK shall do the cast :  https://developer.gnome.org/gobject/stable/gobject-Closures.html#G-CALLBACK:CAPS

events.target_title: Add modern look to resource tab

note.body: I'm not at ease with cairo, but the static variables `save_w` and `save_h` in `cpu_core_configure_event` must cause trouble because they are shared between widgets. I'm not sure you need the optimisation (remove the part that check if configure-event width and height changed)

note.body:
I've tried upgrading to 0.30.7, but that did not work.

It indeed looks that exiv2 errors are red herring - there are fewer errors of that kind than invocation of ThumbnailCache.vala.

```
   4466 [CRT] Directory Samsung2 with 21313 entries consid
   5042 [DBG] ThumbnailCache.vala:213: import from source:
```

I can also confirm this only affects the DNG files.

note.body:
>  Another question: Did you deliberatly switch your developer to shotwell?

I've possibly played with this setting while ago, but it's been a few years since. My current preference would be to use camera developer, where possible, unless I've previously applied transformations to the resulting photo.

There are two "backingphotos" entries for DNG, one has incorrect DB record. Notably, the physical file for `sg107709.jpg` does exist under `/home/maciej/media/photos/shotwell`. Apart of the path, which can be corrected, is tnat even a correct conceptual model, i.e. are backingphotos many-to-one to DNG? If not, then it should have a constraint in place to prevent it.

How do we get from "backing photo does not exist" to "regenerate thumbnail"? Correct me if this is wrong please, but isn't a thumbnail a property of a photo? The logic for thumbnail regeneration should be then something like: "if thumbnail does not exist, generate it using one of (perhaps freshest) backing photos". 

I'd also add a warning level log to surface the fact that files referred by the DB are missing.

events.target_title: Persistent re-generation of thumbnails for DNG files

note.body:
It sounds that what is needed here is to extract out the logic for determining which backing photo is to be displayed as the main one.

When external edit is made, does the result always take the precedence in the UI when choosing what to display as a full photo? If so, that precedence should be followed, i.e. I'd abstract out the logic of "primary_backing_photo" and only generate the thumbnail after evaluating whether the existing one originates from the latest instance of the primary backing photo. 

To support the external edit use case, Shotwell should somehow validate whether thumbnail is still up-to-date, e.g. by looking at the timestamp of the latest primary backing photo and comparing it either with db record or perhaps information embedded in the thumbnail itself. DB approach would use less IO.

note.body:
> GNOME Shell's screenshot functionality provides NO (or faulty) feedback on selected area with EXWM (Emacs X Window Manager)

This bug seems neither in EXWM *exclusively* or GNOME Shell *exclusively* but in the interaction between the GNOME Shell and EXWM.

I have filed a bug report with EXWM as well.  See [https://github.com/ch11ng/exwm/issues/628](https://github.com/ch11ng/exwm/issues/628).

I have seen the above bug with `gnome-shell 3.30.2-11`. I was hoping that this commit [screenshot: Don't pick up rubberband style from GTK (a5c75ff5) · Commits · GNOME / gnome-shell · GitLab](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/commit/a5c75ff58b8510b92b325d136b8bd67e1b4174f6) may have a bearing on the issue at hand.  So, waited until `gnome-shell 3.34` to hit debian unstable.

FWIW, for the diff in window manager capabilities between `Metacity` and `EXWM`, see attachments at https://github.com/ch11ng/exwm/issues/628#issuecomment-532157953

EXWM owner says this

> Haven't tried an older build of gnome-shell but _GTK_FRAME_EXTENTS may have something to do with this problem. It's private to GTK and perhaps only a few WMs have support for it. 


I am a programmer / developer myself.  If I could get some hints on how to debug GNOME Shell (on GNOME Flashback desktops),  I can help with narrowing the issue further.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell (3.34.1-1)'s screenshot functionality provides NO (or faulty) feedback on selected area with EXWM (Emacs X Window Manager)

note.body:
> On Xorg, gnome-shell *is* the window manager. If you are using any other window manager - metacity, exwm, you name it - you are therefore *not* using gnome-shell.

I am using `GNOME Flashback`.

If you look at the video I posted, the screenshot is taken with `gnome-screenshot`.  `gnome-screenshot` invokes GNOME Shell's screenshot facility, when it is available.  See https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-screenshot/blob/e0c4cd438a1e8225499a44dbca4013e3dc92e7d9/src/screenshot-area-selection.c#L314 and a few lines above that.

The videos I shared shows that GNOME Shell's area select and screenshot facility are indeed available over dbus.

> Whatever your issue is, it is not a gnome-shell problem (which is only responsible for taking screenshots if you are running it).

My video *proves* that it is indeed GNOME Shell's that is taking the screenshot.  (I agree that GNOME Shell is not acting as the window manager.)  

May be you got carried away by mention of window manager.

I am re-opening the bug.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell (3.34.1-1)'s screenshot functionality provides NO (or faulty) feedback on selected area with EXWM (Emacs X Window Manager)

note.body:
>  Florian Müllner @fmuellner added 3. Not GNOME label 4 hours ago

It is definitely a GNOME problem.  If GNOME Shell shouldn't be taking the screenshot, why is `gnome-screenshot` even doing a dbus invocation of Gnome Shell's screenshot function.  Shouldn't it be falling back to taking screenshot natively.

I would appreciate if you would allow some discussion to take place before you decide whether or not the bug belongs to GNOME or not.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell (3.34.1-1)'s screenshot functionality provides NO (or faulty) feedback on selected area with EXWM (Emacs X Window Manager)

note.body:
```elisp
(dbus-call-method
 :session
 "org.gnome.Shell.Screenshot"
 "/org/gnome/Shell/Screenshot"
 "org.gnome.Shell.Screenshot"
 "SelectArea"
 :timeout 120000)

```

The one you see above is precisely the dbus call that `gnome-screenshot` is making @ https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-screenshot/blob/e0c4cd438a1e8225499a44dbca4013e3dc92e7d9/src/screenshot-area-selection.c#L342.  It is precisely the dbus call I make in the above videos.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell (3.34.1-1)'s screenshot functionality provides NO (or faulty) feedback on selected area with EXWM (Emacs X Window Manager)

note.body:
> If you are using any other window manager - metacity, exwm, you name it - you are therefore *not* using gnome-shell.

GNOME Shell indeed provides screenshot facility over dbus.  If a dbus client cannot select area or take screenshot using dbus calls, shouldn't GNOME Shell return a failure code.

For the sake of record, `gnome-screenshot` WORKS WELL on `metacity`.  It DOES NOT  WORK WELL on `EXWM`, `i3` + `gnome-flashback`, and also  on `OpenBox`.

events.target_title: Unable to open folders in Mac Catalina: "Operation not permitted"

note.body:
I'm running Gimp 2.8 on OS X Catalina 10.15

A workaround for the meantime;
In the terminal:

$ cd /Applications/Gimp.app

$ ./Contents/MacOS/Gimp

Launching the app in this way will route the permissions dialogs through the Terminal app. When I tested this (inspiration is from the inkscape bug report) I launched Gimp using the above command, then used "File > Open" and navigated to my Desktop. 

I then get a popup saying "Terminal wants to access files on your Desktop" I clicked allow and now Gimp functions as normal.

The situation looks quite similar to the one with the Thinkpad X1 Yoga 2nd gen
(see my comments on [issue #12][1] of libwacom).
The tablet and stylus somehow work, but the stylus is not recognized in Settings > Devices > Wacom Tablet panel. If that is the case, a definition for the stylus pen of the X1 Yoga 3rd gen might be missing. Following the discussion in that issue, simply adding the pen definition and updating the tablet definition in /usr/share/libwacom might fix it. 

You might want to add a comment in libwacom [issue #17][2], that introduces tablet support for the Thinkpad X1 Yoga 3rd gen but without stylus info. Following up the discussion there will hopefully lead to the solution of the problem. 

  [1]: https://github.com/linuxwacom/libwacom/issues/12#issuecomment-530486669
  [2]: https://github.com/linuxwacom/libwacom/issues/17

events.target_title: No commits shown in shallow repositories

note.body:
!110 mostly works. gitg crashes when you click on the commit with missing parents. This is due to missing null checks at [`libgitg/gitg-commit.vala#L138`](libgitg/gitg-commit.vala#L138) and [`libgitg/gitg-diff-view-commit-details.vala#L224`](libgitg/gitg-diff-view-commit-details.vala#L224). This patch adds those checks: [gitg-3.32.1-libgitg-check-for-null.patch](/uploads/821fe50b80d1b1c2e6c634605839af4b/gitg-3.32.1-libgitg-check-for-null.patch).

I'm not going to send a merge request for it, because I suspect that the upstream changes will make it so that nulls are not returned.

note.body:
It seems that you are correct in that the values are not interchangeable - though they are very close which is what lead me to initially conclude they are.

From what I can see they appear to correspond to the position of the `realWindow`'s `metaWindow` instead of the `realWindow` itself. Between windows, the comparative sort of these properties should be the same - though I may not be accounting for every case.

The same performance can indeed be achieved by separately caching the values of `realWindow` - though in addition the example provided there would have to be a hook to update them.

events.target_title: workspace: Sort windows in overview grid using cached bounding box

note.body:
> IMHO it is safe to assume that the (real) window doesn't move while the overview is open. Even if the position changes, the window isn't visible on screen, so reacting to the change would be unexpected.

Ah, I had mistakenly assumed that window clones were re-used and not re-created on opening the overlay.

In that case the center could indeed be initialised on creation and that should be sufficient. This still incurs more of a performance penalty than accessing the `metaWindow` properties but if it is incorrect to use them then I suppose there's little that can be done about that.

events.target_title: HSTS (RFC 6797) support for "On The Web" calendars

note.body:
>  Thanks for a bug report.

Thanks for your answer.

>  I do not understand one thing: why do you not set the calendar to use https:// at the first place?

Yes, that would also make sure that an attacker can't obtain the credentials. But if a user enters by accident an `http://` URL or the server didn't support HTTPS when the calendar was added (but does now), the user should be protected anyway. And this is exactly what HSTS is for.

>  I guess this is about:  
>  https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

Yes, exactly.

>  [...] though the code cannot know before it talks to the server.

Yes, the first request has to happen via HTTP, because as you said the client can't know that the server sends this `Strict-Transport-Security` header before sending a request.
However, the client can remember that the server sent this header and do all subsequent requests (each time the calendar is refreshed) directly via HTTPS.
Then the credentials would only be vulnerable when the calendar is added (which can't be prevented), but for the refreshing of the calendar (which happens usually a lot more often) the credentials would be securely transmitted via HTTPS, greatly reducing the chances for an attacker to obtain them.

This is a standard feature in modern browsers (see the *Browser compatibility* table [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security)) and e.g. newer versions of Thunderbird support it for online calendars.

>  These things are done on the evolution-data-server side, thus I move this there.

Thanks, I wasn't sure where this issue belongs.

events.target_title: HSTS (RFC 6797) support for "On The Web" calendars

note.body:
>  I would not overwrite the URL in the configuration, in case the server would change its mind in the future (unlikely, but theoretically possible)

Yes, I don't think that overwriting the URL is the right solution.

>  [...] thus the first request will always go to the address specified by the user and if its response will contain that `Strict-Transport-Security` header, then the next try it'll do with https:// instead.

But this doesn't solve the issue because if the first request is always done via HTTP, a MITM attacker can intercept it and e.g. simply not do the redirect to HTTPS and then the credentials would be vulnerable again.

I think the correct solution would be to save the URL the user entered as it is and additionally a flag if the server sent an HSTS header or not together with when it expires. Then for each request to a URL the user entered with `http://`, the client can check if the HSTS header is still valid and use HTTPS if it is, otherwise use HTTP. It is also important to ignore the header if it is sent via HTTP (not HTTPS), as stated [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security):

> The Strict-Transport-Security header is ignored by the browser when your site is accessed using HTTP; this is because an attacker may intercept HTTP connections and inject the header or remove it. When your site is accessed over HTTPS with no certificate errors, the browser knows your site is HTTPS capable and will honor the Strict-Transport-Security header.

> I do not think there's anything private here, thus I'm unsetting the flag on this report.

Okay, I marked the issue as confidential because it's security-related, just to be sure.

events.target_title: HSTS (RFC 6797) support for "On The Web" calendars

note.body:
Thanks for implementing this so fast, but I think it doesn't fix the issue completely.

Each time evolution-data-server is restarted, the `hsts_until_time` is discarded because it is just stored in RAM and therefore the first request after a restart is again done unencrypted via HTTP. This is also the case when the calendar is removed from Evolution and added again.

To correctly implement HSTS, I think it is necessary to store the `hsts_until_time` permanently on disk and don't remove it if a calendar is removed, i.e. store it per domain, not per calendar URL.

events.target_title: HSTS (RFC 6797) support for "On The Web" calendars

note.body:
> I didn't want to store it anywhere but in memory.

But the HSTS specification requires that it is stored persistently:

> UAs need to retain persistent data about web sites that signal strict security policy enablement, for time spans declared by the web sites.

(see [RFC 6797 - 2.4.1.1. Detailed Core Requirements](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-2.4.1.1))

events.target_title: Link to swedish manual does´nt work.

PDF files opened on second monitor instead of main monitor
Bullet indentation lost when copying text from gnote

note.body:
There was a workaround for this in Tomboy that doesn't exist in GNote.  In Tomboy, there was an AddIn function for Export to HTML [1] which preserved indentation in HTML format.  The HTML could then be cut'n'pasted into the usual OpenOffice Writer or Microsoft Office word processing apps for use in other documents.

It would be a good improvement to have the HTML export function as a core feature.

[1] https://help.gnome.org/users/tomboy/stable/addins-tools.html.en
Export to HTML
The Export to HTML addin is enabled by default and will export an individual note to HTML.

To export a note to HTML, press the Tools icon in the note toolbar and choose Export to HTML. You will immediately be presented with a dialog to save the note. Choose the directory you wish to save the note in and change the name of note's new html file if you wish it to be different than the note name. The note will then be saved as an HTML file and automatically displayed in your browser.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.12 exports broken HEIF/HEIC images when size is 63x63px or smaller
GIMP 2.10.12 exports broken HEIF/HEIC images when size is 63x63px or smaller

note.body:
Dear Massimo, thanks a lot for the link, very helpful!
Indeed, the issue seems to be related/the same. 
I was also thinking about reporting the case when GIMP “mysteriously drops a pixel”, but it is also covered there. Among other sizes, Apple requires 87x87 and 167x167 icons (https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/ios/icons-and-images/app-icon/). GIMP cannot save these sizes in HEIF/HEIC, silently makes them 86x86 and 166x166.
Having read [Dirk Farin comments that you linked](https://github.com/strukturag/libheif/issues/130#issuecomment-494845636), I tried Microsoft Paint that comes with latest Windows 10 ver.1903. It can save both 63x63 (small icon) and 87x87 (without dropping a pixel). GIMP can open these files. When saving (menu File->Overwrite [].heic), GIMP destroys 63x63, 87x87 becomes 86x86.
I attach both [63x63.heic](/uploads/2d273073ee5a0263d5ec237b355a6f72/63x63.heic) and [87x87.heic](/uploads/952af54dccbcd0f38285cd5eab13e99a/87x87.heic) files, in case it helps to evaluate how the image format issue is resolved by Microsoft Paint.
This is low priority for my case, as for very small icons the file size difference between JPEG and HEIF/HEIC is negligible.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.12 exports broken HEIF/HEIC images when size is 63x63px or smaller

note.body:
Thank you for the clarification regarding libheif!
The iOS app displays images in HEIF/HEIC format, to noticeably reduce size. For consistency, I just thought about employing the same format for icons instead of usual JPEG. It seems though that XCode works more maturely with JPEG too, so I have converted all icons to JPEG.
